title: Question 14

children: This question has been updated as a result of postpublication analysis and/or new data that are relevant to the question.

A 23-year-old woman undergoes follow-up after treatment for gonococcal arthritis; she was treated with ceftriaxone. Medical history is notable for meningococcal meningitis as a child. The patient takes no medications.
On physical examination, she feels well with complete resolution of symptoms. Vital signs are normal, and the examination is unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most appropriate screening test to perform next?

Patients with terminal complement deficiency should receive the conjugate and serogroup B meningococcal vaccines.
This patient should be evaluated for a defect in terminal complement level by testing the total hemolytic complement (CH

). She has a personal history of disseminated gonorrhea and meningococcemia. The terminal complement pathway includes C5 to C9, which together form the membrane attack complex, or MAC. The MAC plays a key role in host immunity against

species, and deficiency of a late complement component is associated with an up to 10,000-fold increased risk of meningococcal disease. Counterintuitively, although patients with terminal complement deficiencies are at increased risk of disseminated
infection, including meningococcal meningitis, these tend to be relatively mild and are rarely life-threatening. A personal history of recurrent

infections among multiple family members is an indication to test for terminal complement deficiency. Some studies suggest up to a 20% prevalence of complement deficiency among patients with invasive meningococcal disease, justifying screening at the time of initial presentation, regardless of family history. In patients with a low CH

level, more specialized testing can be performed to identify the specific protein deficiency. Patients with deficiencies in terminal complement levels should receive the conjugate and serogroup B meningococcal vaccines.
